revisions.rev:
{{Expandfurther|date=February 2011}} '''Ahmed Maher''', (born 2 December 1980 in Alexandria), is one of the [[co-founder]]s of the [[April 6 Youth Movement]], and a prominent participant in the anti-[[Mubarak]] demonstrations in [[Egypt]] in 2011.<ref>Esam Al-Amin, [http://www.counterpunch.com/amin02042011.html From Counter-Attack to Departure Day], Counterpunch, 4 February 2011</ref><ref>David Wolman, [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/leading-egyptian-facebook-activist-arrested-friends-say/ Did Egypt Detain a Top Facebook Activist?] , Wired, 2 February 2011</ref>
Maher is a civil engineer<ref>CyberDissidents.org,[http://www.cyberdissidents.org/bin/dissidents.cgi?id=3&c=EG Ahmed Maher]</ref> who works for a construction firm in [[New Cairo]].
Maher attempted to organize several demonstrations after April 2008<ref>Sherif Mansour, [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jun/02/opinion/oe-mansour2 Egypt's Facebook showdown], Los Angeles Times, 2 June 2008</ref>. However, his efforts were hindered both by interference from Egyptian security forces<ref>Liam Stack,[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2008/0730/p04s04-wome.html Egypt detains Facebook activists â again], [[Christian Science Monitor]], 30 July 2008</ref><ref>David Wolman, [http://www.wired.com/techbiz/startups/magazine/16-11/ff_facebookegypt Cairo Activists Use Facebook to Rattle Regime], Wired, 23 July 2008</ref> and internal divisions within the April 6 movement. In June 2010, Maher helped organize a protest against the killing, by Egyptian police, of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Said]], a young resident of [[Alexandria]]. Maher has expressed support for the potential bid of [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] for the Egyptian presidency<ref>[[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]], [http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/01/profile-of-ahmed-maher Profile of Ahmed Maher], (accessed on 8 Feb 2011)</ref>.
